content.en:
This may sound easy but if you want to be on time in Lund there are a few things you should know. There is a system that at first will mess things up for you but don't worry you will learn to love it. The system is called the academic quarter. This ancient habit derives from times when watches were scarce among students.

â³ Simple and Double Quarter âŒ›
Students trusted the cathedral's bells and began their walk to their lectures as the bells chimed at each hour. After 15 minutes everyone had arrived and the lecture could start. The academic quarter can be found in two varities: simple quarter and double quarter. Simple quarter is applied every weekday from 7 AM to 5 PM. Double quarter is applied every weekday from 6 PM to 6 AM, also during weekends and holidays at all hours.
The simple quarter means that when given the time 8 the event will begin at 8:15. All your lectures will be given this way. This means that they all normally begin 15 minutes past the hour. Double quarter on the other hand means that when given the time 19 the event begins at 19:30. This is how the time is given for a sittning for example. In the old days this was because students needed the extra time after the bells had chimed, that is two quarters instead of one, to change into their finest armour.

â€¢ The â€œprickâ€s â€¢
Occasionally you could want an event to begin on the hour. This is called the â€œprickâ€ system. Prick is the Swedish word for a dot and we say prick because you use a period after the given time. This is how you use it in a sentance â€œWe'll meet outside the store at three prick to buy some pigs feet and mulled wineâ€.
The prick is applied in the following manner: one subtracts 15 minutes from the given time. However you cannot override the simple quarter with two pricks. Writing 15(..) on a weekday is like trying to take the cross product of a vector and a scalar, it doesn't work.

Take note on the following examples:
During weekdays 8 means 8:15
During weekdays 15(.) means 15:00
During the weekend 15(.) means 15:15
During the weekend 15(..) means 15:00
If you, in spite of the academic spirit, don't want to use pricks to cancel out the academic quarter you can also choose to state minutes. That is if you write 13:00 or 19:00 you emphasize that the event begins on the hour. Lastly you should know that exams, tests and laborations almost always start at the given time. That is without the academic quarter.

content.en:
There are many different options of clothing in the student world here in Lund. This can seem confusing for the untrained eye. Here is a desciption of the most common items.

ğŸ§‘â€âœˆï¸ The Teknolog Cap ğŸ§‘â€âœˆï¸
The teknolog cap is a cap meant for engineering students. It is an improvement of the Swedish graduate cap. A tongue hangs on the right hand side with a tassel. The tassel's string carries spegater. A spegat is a braided band of varying colour. The colour tells the story of what the student has been up to lately. Every spegat symbolizes a started year and the latest one is placed on top. A student of engineering physics has a orange spegat, engineerings mathematics has orange with silver and engineering nano had orange with green.
If you have taken a sabbatical you sport your tassel with a black spegat. A white and blue one symbolizes a sabbatical working with teknologkaÌŠren. Different schools have differing rules and colours, both for the cap itself and for spegater. The placement of the spegat has different meanings. The further up on the string your spegat is the easier you are to bring home. If you are really desperate you simply toss the tassel over the cap. The opposite of being desperate is being in a relationship. Then your partner ties a knot on your string and vice versa if your partner is blessed with a teknolog cap too. The closer the knot is to the spegater the more serious the relationship is. When you finally finish your studies you hang a padlock in your tassel to prevent additional spegater. Afterwards the key is traditionally thrown into the lake Lake.

The teknolog cap has two varities: the white festive cap and the blue winter cap. The festive cap is worn from the last of april to the fourth of october, but also when TeknologkaÌŠren announces festivities, proms for example. When the festive cap is not born you wear the winter cap. This cap is usually decorated with pins and other pretty objects. The winter cap is worn more frequently and during less serious events. As a nolla (zero) you get to put on your own cap when you officially become an etta (a student of the first year at LTH) during the Nollegasque. This means drinking your cap in. It is strictly forbidden to wear the teknolog cap as a nolla!

Dress code
A dress code will be given before sittningar and parties to notify the guests of the suitable attitre. The dresscode should be followed to the best extent.
We have a dresscode to make the process of picking clothing easier for the guests. Furthermore it avoids a situation where guests feel uncomfortable with what they are wearing compared to the other guests. Here is a quick rundown of the most common dresscodes of LTH.

ğŸ§¡ Overall (ovve) ğŸ§¡
A dress code that requires you to come in your engineering overall. The F-guild overalls are orange, the colour of light with the wavelength 6122 aÌŠngstroÌˆms. This is suitable for party as well as play and everyday use. Overalls can and should be decorated to give it a personal touch. Suitable on a overall would for example be patches of different sorts and parts of overalls from other guilds (parts of leg or arm you can trade without problem, other parts you should be more careful with ). An overall should be worn often and with pride, a well used overall the best kind of overall!

ğŸ•´ï¸ Kavaj ğŸ•´ï¸
The dresscode â€œkavajâ€œ (suit jacket) is the dresscode that can confuse even the most experienced F-guilder. It does not mean that you should wear just your suit jacket as the word implies. It means that gentlemen should were a dark suit and ladies should were something nicer than normal, preferably a dress.

ğŸ’ƒ HoÌˆgtidsdraÌˆktğŸ•º
This is the dresscode for the fancier events like a special sittning, proms, or when you recieve your Nobel prize. The dresscode is also known as white tie and requires a tail coat or a full length evening gown. You can also wear a military uniform or a traditional folk costume. In Lund this dresscode is mainly used for proms. The Nollegasque will have this dress code but it is not strict.

content.en:
When can you burst into a song? What do you do when your neighbour at the table raises his glass to you with an expectant look in his eye? At what sittning is it acceptable to plunder someone else's plate? Here is a rundown of what you need to know when you attend a sittning!

Types of Sittnings
The word sittning can mean many different things but it is usually divided into two categories; tidy and wild. A tidy sittning usually means dress code Kavaj but at some occasions also HoÌˆgtidsdraÌˆkt. Another word for a tidy sittning is gasque, but this word could also refer to the Gaque Hall at KaÌŠrhuset (where a Gasque is usually held). Wild sittnings usually means dress code Overall or to dress up according to the theme of the sittning. This kind of sittning is usually called slasque.Something you always bring no matter what kind of sittning is your song book. The F-guild had its' own song book. Some guilds also have their own and others use TeknologkaÌŠren's song book. There is also an english song book with the most common songs in both English and Swedish. The F-guild bookis what will be used during the nollning. The song book is filled with songs forevery occasion. It is recommended that you attach a pen to your book so that the party at your table can put drawings and jokes in it. If there is not a pen attached they may do something worse. At a wild sittning it is not unusual that a bunch guests will yell â€œTempo!â€. This implies that these guests are of the opinon that there is too little singing to be found and the Master of Ceremonies must annouce a song that everyone can join to sing. At tidy sittnings you never call Tempo and the Master of Ceremonies decides when and what song to sing.

ğŸ­ How to Behave at a Sittning ğŸ­
The clever student realises that different sittnings require different behaviours. At sittnings with the dresscode overall you are not expected to follow the sameguidelines as you would a tidy sittning. At a gasque good manners are in place. During a gasque the table lady is to the right of the table gentleman.It is important to remind you that Tempo is not allowed at a gasque. At a slasque however it is the patience of the Head of festivities that decides where the limit is.

ğŸ¥‚ Cheers ğŸ¥‚
Cheers shall be done often! But in order to cheer you need to know the following rules. During a sittning you may cheer with a single person at any good time. During a slasque you may cheer with the whole of your table, however this is frowned upon at a gasque. The third option is the big cheer that the Master of Ceremonies announces. This type of cheer follows a certain pattern. A lady will first look into the eyesof the fellow to the left of her and they both raise their glasses. The lady is holding the glas with her right hand. She then turns to face the fellow on her right and repeats the procedure, now with the glas in her left hand. She then puts the glas back in her right hand and raises her glas to the fellow straight across from her and drinks. After this she repeats the whole procedure in the opposite order. To summarize: look left, then right, straight ahead, drink, look straight ahead, turn right, then left. Gentlemen follow the same rules but they start by turning to their right.

ğŸ¤¹ Gyckel ğŸ¤¹
A gyckel is a short (but in some cases way too long) performance in two acts. It is fun to do and one should take every oppertunity to perform a gyckel! The Master of Ceremonies signs you up for a gyckel and presents you when it is time. A gyckel is called a spex by some guilds but this is wrong! During a gyckel it is important to show respect. The audience shows respect by not eating and only drinking water during the gyckel. You should also sit still and be mostly quiet during the performance.

ğŸ¾ The Procedure of a Sittning ğŸ¾
If the sittning, according to the guide for example, begins at 19 this means that a predrink will be served at 19:00 and that the actual sittning begins at 19:30 (according to the academic quarter system). Those who arrive later than 19:30 may not be let in. A sittning begins with the song â€œMaÌŠltidssaÌŠngenâ€. Thereafter the guests are served an appetizer, a main course and a dessert. The sittning ends with the song â€œO Gamla Klang och Jubeltidâ€. During the song you slam the table at some given words.
